description: From earlier English creast, from Middle English crest (“ridge, crest”). More at crest.

entries.meaning: A line or mark made by folding or doubling any pliable substance; hence, a similar mark, however produced.
examples: His pants had a nice sharp crease.
His shirt was brand new with visible creases from its store fold.

entries.meaning: (cricket) One of the white lines drawn on the pitch to show different areas of play; especially the popping crease, but also the bowling crease and the return crease.
(lacrosse) The circle around the goal, where no offensive players can go.
(ice hockey, handball) The goal crease; an area in front of each goal.

examples: (To Ali G): My skin is so dry. So for being a bad boy, I want you to rub oil into me, paying special attention to my breasts and my batty crease.

verbs.description: crease (third-person singular simple present creases, present participle creasing, simple past and past participle creased)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a crease in; to wrinkle.
(intransitive) To undergo creasing; to form wrinkles.

examples: The bullet just creased his shoulder.

entries.meaning: (UK, colloquial, intransitive or reflexive, progressive tenses only) To laugh.
examples: I can't breathe, I'm creasing so hard.
the cursed Malayan crease, and battle-clubs / From the isles of palm

verbs.description: crease (third-person singular simple present creases, present participle creasing, simple past and past participle creased)

examples: Then a Malay creased Richard Hunt, who escaped for a moment up the ropes.
